Hi Ken:
      
  I hope some day to do some serious research, at the momen=
t I have to
fight in the wild Automation business day by day and "everythin=
g for
yesterday". 
   But, about LSTM I have a version of LSTM-NEAT that I =
can share
(it=B4s a little dirty I have to separate from other software.  I=
 hope
to have enough time next week). I would like to write some paper abou=
t
the experiments and any suggestion about how to orientate is welcome. 

	=
About second project I have some ideas, but nothing write. In the
next two =
month I am going to deal with a very complex project for a
multinational (a=
utomotive sector) where are involved vision
classifiers. I have several opt=
ions to solve the problem, but one of
them very interesting is to use a row=
-eye with a "guide knowledge
space searching" (after a data reduction) . In=
 this case, due to the
commercial purposes  I will try to communicate as mu=
ch as I can.

Germ=E1n.

    

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanle=
y" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> 
> Germ=E1n, sounds like some interesting proje=
cts.  Do you have any 
> software or papers you can share with more informa=
tion?
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "gbravoescobar" <gbravoesc=
obar@y...> 
> wrote:
> > 
> > Hi,
> > 
> >     Some months have been since =
my last mail, I have been 
> researching
> > two stuffs:
> > 
> > 1)  Use o=
f Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) with NEAT  (see
> > http://www.idsia.ch/~ju=
ergen/lstm/ to know more about LSTM).
> > 2)  Development of Work methods t=
o use NEAT-LSTM and some 
> classifiers
> > like Cascade-Adaboost to solve =
real Automation Industry problems 
> in a
> > feasible way.
> > 
> > 
> > 1=
) NEAT-LSTM:
> > Abstract:
> >        The LSTM are a cell of neurons that a=
re able to store a 
> value
> > during long periods. That is a problem in a=
ll Recurrent Networks,
> > values are difficult to store more than 10-50 it=
erations in the
> > network (see LSTM Link for references). 
> > 
> > 	I pu=
t LSTM inside a NEAT. The evolution make NEAT to use 
> LSTM cells
> > in a=
 productive way storing key values, recovering that values when
> > they ar=
e useful a forgetting them  if it is useful (The 3 LSTM cell
> > functions)=
.
> > 
> > 	My analysis of some of the solved problems suggest that LSTM 
>=
 helps to
> > NEAT in some problems to reduce greatly the searching space 
=
> helping to
> > memorize (some times to accumulate) some important key eve=
nts that 
> are
> > used after to get out the right outputs.
> > 
> > 	An i=
ntuitional example about reduction of searching space is 
> serial
> > XOR,=
 if you solve serial XOR with NEAT you can see that the 
> solution
> > net=
 use recurrent connection to store the first value and later it
> > compare=
s with second value in the serial sequence. In my computer 
> (P4
> > 2,4Gh=
z) it last around  2 minutes to find a solution with NEAT 
> alone.
> > How=
ever, when I use one LSTM cell in the NEAT-LSTM it last ONLY 5
> > SECONDS!=
!!!!.
> > 
> > 2)  Improving Work Methods in Real Automation Problems:
> > =

> >       Motivation: Evolution systems have been achieving great 
> resul=
ts
> > in last years. In my daily work in automation projects business, I
>=
 > have to face another problem: cost. That is the reason that most of
> > =
the times the industry try to avoid complex systems. Complex 
> systems
> >=
 are difficult to develop, difficult to modify and difficult to
> > mainten=
ance. Most of the times, it is the last choosen resource. 
> > 
> > 	Other =
problems to use evolution systems are the 
> uncertainty.  Always,
> > ther=
e is some likelihood that a problem will converge to a 
> solution in
> > a=
 reasonable time. Some time we can evaluate it, sizing the 
> searching
> >=
 space. Other times it very difficult to size such space. 
> Uncertainty
> =
> is a variable related to, what is known in business as, risk. 
> > 
> > 	=
Some recent experiment as in 
> > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/=
whiteson.gecco03.pdf 
> suggest
> > that a way to reduce searching space is=
 to "draw" the guide
> > where the
> > solution will be searched. Some of m=
y research has gone in that
> > direction. In most of the systems we have d=
eal with, we have some
> > previous knowledge about them. My work is focusi=
ng in how organize
> > such previous knowledge in: decision trees, tasks, a=
bstraction 
> levels
> > and interdependences among them to reduce as much =
as possible the
> > searching space. So the final goal is to find feasibili=
ty work 
> methods
> > and tools to use evolution systems in real automatio=
n Industry
> > problems.
> > 
> > Regards.
> > 
> > Germ=E1n.
